technologies.name: PWA
technologies.description: Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are web apps built and enhanced with modern APIs to deliver enhanced capabilities, reliability, and installability while reaching anyone, anywhere, on any device, all with a single codebase.

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. technologies.name: Cart Functionality
technologies.description: Websites that have a shopping cart or checkout page, either using a known ecommerce platform or a custom solution.

technologies.name: Node.js
technologies.description: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform, JavaScript runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

technologies.name: React
technologies.description: React is an open-source JavaScript library for building user interfaces or UI components.

technologies.name: styled-components
technologies.description: Styled components is a CSS-in-JS styling framework that uses tagged template literals in JavaScript.

technologies.name: Next.js
technologies.description: Next.js is a React framework for developing single page Javascript applications.

technologies.name: Matomo Analytics
technologies.description: Matomo Analytics is a free and open-source web analytics application, that runs on a PHP/MySQL web-server.

technologies.name: jsDelivr
technologies.description: JSDelivr is a free public CDN for open-source projects. It can serve web files directly from the npm registry and GitHub repositories without any configuration.

technologies.name: Taboola
technologies.description: Taboola is a content discovery & native advertising platform for publishers and advertisers.

technologies.name: reCAPTCHA
technologies.description: reCAPTCHA is a free service from Google that helps protect websites from spam and abuse.

technologies.name: HSTS
technologies.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.

technologies.name: Webpack
technologies.description: Webpack is an open-source JavaScript module bundler.

technologies.name: Open Graph
technologies.description: Open Graph is a protocol that is used to integrate any web page into the social graph.

technologies.name: Module Federation
technologies.description: Module Federation is a webpack technology for dynamically loading parts of other independently deployed builds.

alerts.name: Absence of Anti-CSRF Tokens
alerts.desc:
No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

* The victim has an active session on the target site.

* The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

* The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.

alerts.name: Application Error Disclosure
alerts.desc: This page contains an error/warning message that may disclose sensitive information like the location of the file that produced the unhandled exception. This information can be used to launch further attacks against the web application. The alert could be a false positive if the error message is found inside a documentation page.

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: X-Frame-Options Setting Malformed
alerts.desc: An X-Frame-Options header was present in the response but the value was not correctly set.

alerts.name: CSP: Notices
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Dangerous JS Functions
alerts.desc: A dangerous JS function seems to be in use that would leave the site vulnerable.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server - Unix

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.desc: The request appeared to contain sensitive information leaked in the URL. This can violate PCI and most organizational compliance policies. You can configure the list of strings for this check to add or remove values specific to your environment.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.desc: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

alerts.name: Absence of Anti-CSRF Tokens
alerts.desc:
No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive

Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: Cookie without SameSite Attribute
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the SameSite attribute, which means that the cookie can be sent as a result of a 'cross-site' request. The SameSite attribute is an effective counter measure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion
alerts.desc: The page includes one or more script files from a third-party domain.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Multiple Header Entries (Non-compliant with Spec)
alerts.desc:
HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) headers were found, a response with multiple HSTS header entries is not compliant with the specification (RFC 6797) and only the first HSTS header will be processed others will be ignored by user agents or the HSTS policy may be incorrectly applied.

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL).

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.desc: The request appeared to contain sensitive information leaked in the URL. This can violate PCI and most organizational compliance policies. You can configure the list of strings for this check to add or remove values specific to your environment.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.desc: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.

runWarnings: The tested device appears to have a slower CPU than  Lighthouse expects. This can negatively affect your performance score. Learn more about [calibrating an appropriate CPU slowdown multiplier](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse/blob/master/docs/throttling.md#cpu-throttling).

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

attributes.name: Potentiel
attributes.pitch: Faciliter le parcours des producteurs d'énergies renouvelables électriques

ecoindex.label: GES
ecoindex.comment: Pour un total de 2000 visites par mois, ceci correspond à 32km en voiture (Peugeot 208 5P 1.6 BlueHDi FAP (75ch) BVM5)

ecoindex.label: Eau
ecoindex.comment: Pour un total de 2000 visites par mois, ceci correspond à 1 douche
